name: UploadSarifCodeScanningResults
description:
Upload SARIF data to GitHub for code scanning results.

This tool uploads SARIF data from a code scanning analysis to a GitHub repository. Use appropriate access tokens for private or public repositories. Uploaded results appear in pull requests or the repository's security tab, depending on the reference used. SARIF data must be compressed and encoded before uploading.

parameters.name: repository_owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository on GitHub, not case sensitive.

value_schema.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repository_name
parameters.description: The name of the repository. It is not case sensitive and identifies where the SARIF data will be uploaded.

value_schema.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: commit_sha
parameters.description: The SHA of the commit associated with the uploaded analysis. This links the SARIF data to a specific point in the repository's history.

value_schema.description: The SHA of the commit to which the analysis you are uploading relates.

parameters.name: git_reference
parameters.description: The full Git reference. Format: `refs/heads/<branch name>`, `refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.

value_schema.description:
The full Git reference, formatted as `refs/heads/<branch name>`,
`refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.

parameters.name: base64_compressed_sarif_data
parameters.description: A Base64-encoded string of the SARIF file compressed using gzip. Ensure proper encoding before upload.

value_schema.description: A Base64 string representing the SARIF file to upload. You must first compress your SARIF file using [`gzip`](http://www.gnu.org/software/gzip/manual/gzip.html) and then translate the contents of the file into a Base64 encoding string. For more information, see "[SARIF support for code scanning](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server@3.8/code-security/secure-coding/sarif-support-for-code-scanning)."

parameters.name: base_directory_for_analysis
parameters.description: The base directory used in the analysis as it appears in the SARIF file to map file paths correctly.

value_schema.description:
The base directory used in the analysis, as it appears in the SARIF file.
This property is used to convert file paths from absolute to relative, so that alerts can be mapped to their correct location in the repository.

parameters.name: analysis_start_time
parameters.description: The timestamp when the analysis run began, in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

value_schema.description: The time that the analysis run began. This is a timestamp in [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

parameters.name: tool_name
parameters.description: Specifies the tool name used for generating the code scanning analysis. Defaults to 'API' if not provided. Supports filtering by tool GUID in alerts operations.

value_schema.description: The name of the tool used to generate the code scanning analysis. If this parameter is not used, the tool name defaults to "API". If the uploaded SARIF contains a tool GUID, this will be available for filtering using the `tool_guid` parameter of operations such as `GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts`.

metadata.description: Tools that enable LLMs to interact directly with the GitHub API.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

value_schema.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

value_schema.description: The name of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.description:
The base directory used in the analysis, as it appears in the SARIF file.
This property is used to convert file paths from absolute to relative, so that alerts can be mapped to their correct location in the repository.

value_schema.description:
The base directory used in the analysis, as it appears in the SARIF file.
This property is used to convert file paths from absolute to relative, so that alerts can be mapped to their correct location in the repository.

parameters.description:
The full Git reference, formatted as `refs/heads/<branch name>`,
`refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.

value_schema.description:
The full Git reference, formatted as `refs/heads/<branch name>`,
`refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.

parameters.name: sarif
parameters.description: A Base64 string representing the SARIF file to upload. You must first compress your SARIF file using [`gzip`](http://www.gnu.org/software/gzip/manual/gzip.html) and then translate the contents of the file into a Base64 encoding string. For more information, see "[SARIF support for code scanning](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server@3.8/code-security/secure-coding/sarif-support-for-code-scanning)."

value_schema.description: A Base64 string representing the SARIF file to upload. parameters.name: started_at
parameters.description: The time that the analysis run began. This is a timestamp in [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

value_schema.description: The time that the analysis run began. This is a timestamp in [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

If the uploaded SARIF contains a tool GUID, this will be available for filtering using the `tool_guid` parameter of operations such as `GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/code-scanning/alerts`.
